name: FL2 Use of FENZ Operational Vehicles
intro: The learning document for this test is at FL2 Use of FENZ Operational Vehicles in the FENZ Portal (requires to login with your FENZ account)

structure.description: When responding to an emergency incident, when must both siren and beacons be used?
options: Whenever the vehicle is moving
When travelling against the traffic, through red lights or stop signs at intersections
When parking at an incident on the wrong side of the road
When requested by FireComms
structure.correctAnswer: When travelling against the traffic, through red lights or stop signs at intersections

structure.description: If a drivers license has been suspended, disqualified or restricted in any way, who must be notified?
options: No one, it's personal information
The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
Advise your Chief Fire Officer or Manager
The Police
structure.correctAnswer: Advise your Chief Fire Officer or Manager

structure.description: Under what circumstances can a firefighter drive an ambulance in an emergency situation?
options: Never
When requested by the Ambulance OIC, the driver must have a Class 1 license and have current competency in emergency response driving (ERD).
When directed by your OIC
Only if you have been properly inducted and are familiar with the vehicle
structure.correctAnswer: When requested by the Ambulance OIC, the driver must have a Class 1 license and have current competency in emergency response driving (ERD).

structure.description: What is the maximum permitted speed for a heavy operational vehicle responding under lights and siren on the open road? (Type 1 to 4)
options: 130km/h
105km/h
110km/h
Speed limits do not apply to FENZ vehicles

structure.description: What is the maximum permitted speed in a 50 km/h zone when responding under lights and siren to an emergency?
options: 65 km/h
75 km/h
85 km/h
50 km/h

structure.description: What is the maximum speed limit through a temporary speed zone?
options: 15 km/h above the posted speed limit
Up to 105 km/h if the driver considers it safe
The posted speed limit
25 km/h above the posted speed limit

structure.description: What is the maximum speeds permitted at intersections controlled by lights, stop or give way signs in an emergency response?
options: Up to 105 km/h if the driver considers it safe
As fast as the OIC requests me to go
Slow to 10 km/h and stop if necessary, proceed if the way is clear, at a speed not exceeding 20 km/h and provided siren and beacons are operating
Stop at the lights and wait for the green signal
structure.correctAnswer: Slow to 10 km/h and stop if necessary, proceed if the way is clear, at a speed not exceeding 20 km/h and provided siren and beacons are operating

structure.description: When may the driver of a FENZ vehicle use a handheld cellphone?
options: When it is necessary to speak with FireComms and the LMR is not working
When the vehicle has stopped and parked out of the line of traffic or the call is to 111 or *555 and it unsafe or unpractical to stop and park out of the line of traffic
If trying to find directions to the incident
Never
structure.correctAnswer: When the vehicle has stopped and parked out of the line of traffic or the call is to 111 or *555 and it unsafe or unpractical to stop and park out of the line of traffic

structure.description: What is the maximum number of BA cylinders that may be transported in a FENZ vehicle other than a BA Tender?
options: 12 Cylinders
18 Cylinders
24 Cylinders
28 Cylinders

structure.description: The number of persons permitted to be carried in a FENZ vehicle is 1 person per seat belt provided.
What are the two points mentioned in Driving Policy that relate to the driving of private vehicles to or from the station or incident? (Click all that apply)
options: Personnel must observe the posted road speed limit
Speed limit can be exceeded in an emergency
Personnel are not covered by FENZ for damage or loss to a private vehicle
Seat belts are optional for short distances
Private vehicles can be left on yellow lines when attending an incident
correctAnswer: Personnel must observe the posted road speed limit
Personnel are not covered by FENZ for damage or loss to a private vehicle
